utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And can I get your name?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh how can I plan for your trip in Singapore?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Yah, actually I'm planning a trip to Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: %Uh we're just two people, I mean me and my partner.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: %Uh and then we have a budget of one thousand dollars.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Maybe you can help me out on this.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So like one thousand per person?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh right now, I think the conversion is one Singapore Dollars will give you approximately about thirty four Pesos.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So whatever price that I'm gonna quote you will be all in Singapore Dollars.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so it's there and how many days will you be spending in Singapore?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: About one to two days only

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Oh one or two days only yah?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, and is there anything in peculiar that you would like to do here?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Yah, actually I have something in mind.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: I want something %um that me and my partner weren't tried.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: But at the same time, we want something %um which is a bit historical wherein we can learn something about your culture, your traits and you know, different places wherein we can remember Singapore at all times.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so you want to do something historical and %uh this is your first time in Singapore?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh what we can do is- one or two days.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Alright now %uh you will arrive in Changi Airport.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you can take the subway.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: We call ours MRT and I think in Philippines, you call it the same as well.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh all the signs, the street signs will all be written in English.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you will have no problem %uh getting on the subway or travelling around Singapore either by bus or the subway.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So the subway station and Changi Airport is called Changi Airport.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you will take the East West Line.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh if it's like a one day, you can buy a standard ticket but if it's for two days, you can %uh either buy a standard ticket or you can buy the tourist ticket.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Okay, is there any price difference between those tickets.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Oh okay, it's just that the standard %uh- the stored value ticket will be easier for you to travel around but there's actually a five dollars %uh deposit.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh standard ticket, let's say assuming if the price is like a dollar, you have to prepare two dollars.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: At the end of your trip, you just remember to go back to the machine and you'll be able to get the %uh refund of that one dollar.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So I'll just show you in brief %uh the map.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Are you able to see now?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Alright, can you- I think you should be able to see.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so on the right-hand side where you see the number three

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You have to get off the train at Expo.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you will continue with the green line.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh and I guess the- age-wise %uh you're between twenty to thirties.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can get off at- there are few hotels that you can choose from.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, that is %uh one of- well, it's quite a new hotel now called V Hotel.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so that's one hotel that you can choose.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: The next hotel will be at Bugis.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And then if you go to the yellow line, just follow the green line up-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: That's another word called Bras Basah.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: There's another hotel there called the %uh %uh Bayview Hotel.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So these are all %uh budget range hotel.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But I will chose these view hotels because they are very convenient in terms of %uh walking.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: To your- the places of interest.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Have you any idea which %um the three of them is the best one?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: %Uh when it comes to %um services, facilities and everything.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh the three hotels, they do have %um breakfast, they have %uh fitness centre and also they have swimming pool %uh and sauna as well.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So I would say that they are fairly %uh compatible.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh but the one at Lavender, that would be quite a new hotel because they have just opened recently.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But if you want to be like very near to the main shopping area walk to the museum-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: then I would say that the one closer to Bras Basah would be better.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So I think and %uh I'll be choosing that one.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh that would be the Bayview Hotel.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You just cross like the first day, you can do a museum tour.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, just cross across from the hotel and you are at the National %uh Museum of Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So I just need to walk.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes, you just need to walk.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So what you do is you just walk you can spend easily.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Alright, few hours in the museum.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh but I would say a minimum stay of one hour to two hours.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you go in to the newest part of the museum.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can see on the left-hand side, this glass area.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You go in from the older part of the museum, you go into the newer part of the museum.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: inside this gallery itself, you'll be able to learn about the history of Singapore right through from the early nine hundreds to modern day Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Hm you can use the audio guide.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: We have- we do provide audio guides for you.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So do remember to %uh check out the audio guides.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you can do like %uh a one hour inside this history gallery.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: %Um are all things there written in English too or any translation?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you can do this %um %uh tour.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And if you have time, you go back to the older part of the museum.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: We have living galleries in there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But if you don't have, then that's fine.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Now after this, so you can do this in the morning.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, have your lunch in our many hawker centre.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, there's just one just outside your hotel area.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, they have various kinds of food.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Like Chinese food, Indian food, Malay food and we even have fish and chips out in our hawker centre.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Now, one meal %uh will cost you with drinks in the range of eight Singapore Dollars.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So that means like if you have rice with three dishes %uh and a drink.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, that's approximately about eight dollars.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Then from there, you can take the MRT-

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: What can I see in Chinatown?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, because you would have a good idea of the history of Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Generally people came here from all over the world

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh because they were looking for jobs out here-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh so the Chinese came, the Malays from nearby, the Malay archipelago.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh the Indians from Southern part of India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And the Europeans of course, they came and-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: in the beginning, all of them live in this place called Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But eventually it gets crowded so the %uh they moved away from this area.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So the Chinese stayed back in Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Then the Malays moved to this area called Kampong Glam.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And the Indians moved to this area called Little India.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So they have different %uh separate places now.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes, so what we have done is we have preserved all these ethnic areas.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes, so you can actually do Chinatown first in the afternoon.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: That means you can also have your lunch %uh in Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: There's also a non-air conditioned food court %uh in Chinatown itself.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you alight at Chinatown MRT Train Station.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Um there are some other cafes there as well if you want to do your cafes.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Pick up a bit of %uh souvenirs from Chinatown area.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: If I'm going there this %um end of March, can %uh will I ever see any festivities in Chinatown?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Do they have any festival right now?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: we do have a big festival in Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: That would be in %uh January period.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But it's okay, it's still very %um %uh a nice walk around Chinatown because the houses there are preserved.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Alright, they are under conservation status.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So the front part of the buildings are all preserved already.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So there are really ancient %um architectural designs there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: There are- Yah %uh, I would say we also learnt from the Europeans

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: because you will see big windows

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: which allows air to ventilate the whole area.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So that will be their means of ventilation for that house or for that particular building.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, because in the old days, their houses were not air conditioned.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh you can actually see %uh %uh okay, that's another view of Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh you can visit this- on the right-hand side, there's a Buddha relic hotel %uh temple.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Can you see Chinatown Visitor Centre?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can pay a visit to this Chinatown centre.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And again, if you like to really learn more about the people in Chinatown, how- what kind of conditions they were living in.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh just about two street away, there is a Chinatown Heritage Centre.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you can visit there as well and to see how people- in the past, they lived in this very cram condition in Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So like one house will be divided into various cubicles and you can have easily %uh- fifty people living in just one house on one level.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes, so that's something very %uh unique I would say.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh of course we don't live like this anymore but this was how the %uh poor people, the coolies, the labourers, the rickshaw riders they used to live in Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: But %uh what if I wanted to visit a Buddha temple.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Is there any rule that I need to follow because I'm not a Buddhist.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: This Buddha Relic Temple is open to the public.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh just make sure that you are %uh dressed properly.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Like %uh no short skirt, no shorts.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh if you are wearing culotte just you know, have it like %uh touching the knee, below the knee.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: If you are wearing like t-shirt, try to be get %uh wear a t-shirt that has sleeve and you'll be fine.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh if you are- if you should really want to wear short, it's still fine.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Because at the front of the Buddha Relic Temple, they do provide scarfs for you to put on.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh but I would say dressing-wise as in any other place of worship just %uh this would be %uh good enough.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And just down the road %uh I think we can do that just %uh Buddha Relic Temple.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But if you really want to see another Chinese temple, then you have to walk to the %uh temple called Thian Hock Keng Temple.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: That's about %uh fifteen minutes walk away from here.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Do a little bit of lunch.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Appreciate the architecture because the architecture here would be different from the ones in Kampong Glam and Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You know you- I think you can see just above the flowers, there are this green coloured roof %uh that looks like bamboo plants.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so this is- the architecture would be different from the houses in Kampong Glam and Little India.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: %Um is it because it's made up of wood and the one that we have in Little India is made up of that- is that a difference?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh no. The difference %uh- it just looks like %uh bamboo plants, they are made of ceramic.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh and because the Chinese- according to the Chinese, the bamboos represents %uh bamboo.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Alright, look- they look bamboo and according to the Chinese, bamboo means everlasting or long life.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: I thought they are real bamboos.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: No, this is %uh- %uh no. They are not real bamboos.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: They are made of ceramic tiles.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh it's just that they are made to look like bamboos.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So the bamboos according to the Chinese are auspicious %uh symbol.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so you will don't- you will not see this kind of roof over in Kampong Glam and Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so after your walk in Chinatown, I could guess that would be about two P.M.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can go over to %uh Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you take the subway train again that happens to be the correct line.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you will alight at %uh Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And again, it's very straightforward, the main road of Little India is Serangoon Road.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Serangoon, I'll spell it for you.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: A N G O O N.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so it's just one main street.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And out of this main street, you can go to the little streets.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So if you are lost, you just go back to the main street again.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: And then I'll see the %uh subway train again?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So- Yes, when you get up from the Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Chinatown, same station, you take the same line and you alight at Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you will alight at the station called Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: When you come out of the station- but just remember that most of our subway or rather all our subway train station have a few exit.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You just come out to the exit that is towards %uh Little India %uh Arcade.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Okay, but %uh there would be a sign- I mean- a sign.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Yes, signage or someone whom I can ask about it.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: In all our MRT Train Station, there's always a station master.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh you just approach %uh the station master and anyway the signs are all quite clear.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So just alight- %uh I mean just come out from the right side of the MRT Train Station.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And then at the %uh- so the main area will be what we call the Little India Arcade.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: It's just so-called the Little India Arcade.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, then you can do a walk because it's- the whole atmosphere is totally different from Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You will see quite a few flower garland shop.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh because the Indians %uh like flowers because it represents the way of life.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And of course they use- %uh they buy- the Indians buy them or rather the Hindus %uh they buy them and offer the flower garlands to %uh their gods when they go to visit the %uh temples.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So- yes, so you can- you will see like flower garland shop.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You will see %um shops selling vegetables.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Like a market but they are like stand alone shops.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: And they don't have this in the Chinatown, right?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh if you go back to- now I'm still showing the Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: I'm still showing the Chinatown Visitor %uh Complex.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Just on the left hand side, there is a food centre.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: In the basement of the food centre is a market.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, but %uh- so it's like a wet market.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: A wet market, it means the floor is perpetually wet.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So they sell meat, vegetable, fruits, flowers, everything is sold there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But that close at twelve P.M.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh if you want to do a market, you can do that.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And then take a trip to Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So take a trip on the subway to Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Now in Little India, the houses are a little bit different.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Like I mentioned, you will not see %uh houses with this green roof.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: The houses in Little India will be a little bit more simpler in design.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Compared to the ones in Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh take a walk around %uh Little India and %uh soak in the atmosphere out there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And of course do try the Indian pancake called %uh roti prata.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: There's also North Indian food called chapati.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: And do you have any idea how much it will cost %uh eat- I will eat in Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Your eating in Little India, it's not very expensive.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh about eighty cents for a piece of plain roti prata.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you can also have this bread called naan.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Or you can have chapati which is made from wheat flour.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you can eat with your hands.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: If you eating this kind of food-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: okay, nobody will give you funny looks.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And %uh of course if you want to buy some sari-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: the cheapest one would be in the range that's made of poster would be in the range of Singapore Dollars, ten dollars.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you can wear with %uh short %uh blouse.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: if you can see on the map, can you see the word Serangoon Road on the right-hand side?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can see %uh- so that is the whole- the main road of %uh Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Then you can see all the little road that leads out from Serangoon Road.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you will be doing %um- can you see the word Campbell Lane?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Oh %uh there is this- a lot of activities can be found over there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can do %uh henna painting on your hands.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh the You know, when you first apply, it were- it's black in colour but it takes about half an hour to dry.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: When it starts to crack, you will just scrape off.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Leave this orange %uh a stain on your hands, it probably last you about seven days.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So the Indians lady do the henna painting like right now for special occasions when they get married for special %uh festival but otherwise you can do henna painting any time.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: And %um do they have these designs for me or I will be the one whose going to give them a design.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Or I just need to choose a, you know, a typical design wherein they- it's like a tradition from them.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh no, they do have- %uh traditionally of course it's just %uh flowers or geometric design.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So they do have % uh patterns for you to choose.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, the artist are pretty good.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: They can draw for you within like %uh less than five minutes and they are done.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you get about %uh- okay, I just want to show you some of the scene-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: in Chinatown %uh in Little India, this one here.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And the next one is food.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh one of the typical Indian food is called Indian Rojak.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Rojak will be- that means like everything mixed together.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you can choose what you like %uh from potatoes to egg, to meat.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Okay, it's a combination of everything.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes so you choose what you like.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh that they are usually quite colourful and they serve you in this orange looking %uh sauce.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And the next one will be the flower garland shop that I just talked about.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Are all this food spicy and-

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: you know %uh are all of them spicy?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, like the %um %uh Indian Rojak for example.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh the sauce is not that spicy.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Just a little bit spicy but if you don't like spicy food, you can actually skip the sauce.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh for the naan, of course it's not spicy, it's made of %uh wheat flour.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Roti prata, they are all made of flour.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And if you again don't like spicy food, then you skip the %uh curry.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Well some of our younger children, they do eat roti prata with sugar but that's not very traditional.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Or if you again don't- you don't like spicy food, is it?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you can also have your roti prata or your chapati with dhal.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, it's a sauce called dhal.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: It's made from beans so it's not spicy.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So I just need to request this from the salesman?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So instead of getting curry, you ask for dhal.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And %uh that's also a typical food in Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, I think these are quite typical food already in Little India.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, and you can have a drink-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: called lassi, L A S S I.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: It's- it is taste a little bit like yogurt.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Taste a little bit like yogurt.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, but- Okay, it's made up of yogurt.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh but they have added in like the modern %uh taste would be- you can have mango lassi.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: There are all the different kind of fruits %uh that's added into this %uh yogurt drink.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So it's a typical- yah, it's a typical Indian drink.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Okay, and I just need to choose what kind of fruit I wanted to %uh mix with this lassi.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So a meal in %uh food centre would cost you about- with the %uh lassi.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Now, so you can walk around Little India, I gave you a few images for you to see.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And then you can go on to do Kampong Glam.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So remember earlier on I said about the different races that used to live in Singapore and later it was so crowded, they all moved away to different parts of Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So if you're really done your museum tour, that will be a good way to see %uh you know, how the people you %uh live in these different areas.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so the people in Little India, in the past they used to engage in cattle related activities.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So again if you look at the map, there are roads named after buffalos.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, there is- if you walk- look up a bit, it's called- there's another road called Kerbau Road.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: That's also named after buffalos or cows.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So from our street names, you can actually tell what kind of activities, people in the past used to engage in.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you walk a little bit down Serangoon Road, you will come to this %uh Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So from there %uh in the afternoon, the- in the afternoon, the temple is closed but you still can get good photograph of the exterior part of the temple.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And then you just walk to Farrer Park, just walk straight.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Again, you'll come to the MRT called Farrer Park MRT.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And then take a train to Kampong Glam but you have to change train.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh if you are not too tired.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So otherwise you can reserve Kampong Glam for the next day.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Because you'll be doing Chinatown, Little India in the first day.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So like some of the other souvenirs that you may want to pick up in Little India would be like bangles.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can buy bangles for a dollar each.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: For a dollar of %uh a dollar for a few of these plastic bangles.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Sari if it's not too elaborate about Singapore Dollars, ten dollars onwards.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So some shop here they get your henna painting done.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, so that's about five dollars.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So these are the things you want to do then you proceed on either the same day or the next day you go to Kampong Glam.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: If I wanted to go to Kampong Gam at the same day, is there any %um thing I can see at night.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, you try to reach the- let's say %uh- it's still very busy I would say in the night time because there are lot of nice cafe out there.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So there is a night market?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh, no night market in Kampong Glam but there are a lot of cafes and of course the highlight would be the Sultan Mosque.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, it's a mosque so %uh again you have to be appropriately dressed-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: for a visit to the mosque.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh but again if you want to visit the mosque, you try to time your timing let's say before 4:30.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you can visit the mosque but just before the prayer hall.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so have a look, it's a bit different from churches, you don't see chairs inside the prayer hall.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And then just outside the mosque, there's a street, it's a walking- a pedestrian mall called the Bussorah Mall.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Some of the- again like the architecture, take a look, it's quite different from the Little India as well as Chinatown houses.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: No, they are all traditional and conservation houses.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Alright, so we have %uh seen Little India, right?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Because %um as I could see, they have %uh very %um different architectural designs.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You are actually seeing %um a white house, this used to be the Sultan Palace but they are now undergoing %uh restoration.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh Glam is actually named after a tree by the name of the glam tree.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: They used to grow abundantly around this area because they used to be %uh just next to the sea.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Hm so the boats, when they come here for trading, they stop there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And these trees are pretty useful like if there's a small leak on the boat they can use %uh the bark of the tree to repair the small little hole.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh the leaves can be used to make medicine and the bark- the fibres of the tree can be used to make baskets.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So this tree is very useful.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, we don't get to see a lot of this tree but they are still available.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so I'll see- I'll show you now a map of %uh Kampong Glam.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, but you don't need to do the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can just do the small part, alright.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: It's because it's just- if you have ony one hour, that's still fine.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you just walk around this certain street and I like to introduce you to- if you remember the white building that I showed you, that's %uh the Sultan Palace.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, just on outside, there's a street called Kandahar Street.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh and this street has beautiful architecture.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So okay and just spend a bit of time, Just outside the mosque, there's a Bussorah %uh Mall.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can pick up some traditional games and I think you have played them before possibly when you were young like five stone.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %uh so some of these traditional games %uh you can pick them up.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: The- it's like about a dollar each for these kind of toys.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And then you can walk to %um %uh Haji Lane.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: They are just one street away from each other.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you can have your dinner there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So we have like Mediterranean food.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh I would say sorry %uh Mid-Eastern kind of %uh food.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh so you can just pick whichever cafes that you like.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So I can have my dinner there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, and then you can have drinks and you can even try this %uh shisha.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Which are very popular in the Arab countries.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So these are some interesting things that you want to do.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And of course if you want to try out belly dancing as well.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you can also do that in Kampong Glam.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So there are belly dancers there?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So you can just join them.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, you can watch their performance.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can join them or you can even take a short course on belly dancing.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So these are the things you want to do like either the whole day or you can reserve next day for %uh Kampong Glam.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So I think %uh that's about what you can do within one to two days, right?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And of course don't forget a little bit of %uh shopping or people watching in Orchard Road.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Because you are just staying very near.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh just one to two station away from Orchard Road.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, and then of course we have the GST, the seven percent %uh tax rebate.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: If you buy above a hundred dollars from the same shop.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: and which has this sign that says the GST.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Like small little shops, they will not be GST %uh registered so you won't get back your tax refund.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So I just need to go to store which is registered or I'll and they are %um registered to the government?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: No, what you do is let's say you are buying from a big shop, right?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh you just tell them you want a GST form, they will give it to you.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You just fill it up at the airport when you're leaving Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Just make sure that you get it stamped.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh and- when once you clear the immigration, you can get back your money-

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So it's only available with big shops, right?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, the bigger shop that has this GST sign.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: The small little shops, they will not be GST %uh registered so they will not be able to %uh give you the GST form.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Can you also %uh help me if I wanted to %uh go to a place wherein I can relax?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Do you have anything %um where that- wherein I can just visit the seashore?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh what we can do is because we don't have like fine sand in our %uh- on the mainland.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh the nicer beach will be on Sentosa Island.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Otherwise you- if you don't want, we have a beach that- if you don't have to go the Sentosa Island, then it will be on the East Coast.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: And %um it will take me about an hour or

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: how long do I need to travel from my %um hotel to get there?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, you can take the %uh subway train.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh or you can take bus thirty six.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Alright, to go to the East Coast area.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh and just have a sunbathe and just relax or just have a little bit of swim.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh bring a picnic basket %uh to the East Coast.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So I can spend there the whole afternoon before I leave %uh Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And it's also quite close to the airport.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So I can just bring my things there before I leave.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah but it maybe a bit troublesome, right?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Because you have to bring your luggage and all that there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so I suggest that if you still have time, you know like the second day, just relax and then come back, pick up your luggage and then go to the airport.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Do they have the spas there?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: The spa in East Coast- %uh not in the East Coast area, they don't have the spa out there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So our spa will be found mainly %uh in the shopping centre.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Some of the hotels do offer spa.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So I hope I had been helpful to you.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: You had really gave me %um ideas what I, you know when I get there, the things that I'll do.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: By the way, do you have months wherein you celebrate several festival?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: I wanted to see some, you know %um different-

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: If do you have %uh what kind of month do you have this %um celebration of festivals?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh okay, we have the different %uh festivals that's celebrated in Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But %uh if you are coming in April Okay.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: April, we don't have a major festival.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: But %um usually, you %uh what month do you celebrate your festivals?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, we have %uh depending on the year %uh Chinese New Year, usually January where we have this major festival in Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh September would be the Mooncake Festival.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Hari Raya, some time in August.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And Deepavali was be some time in October.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: What would be the events for the %uh this Mooncake Festival.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: you will see a lot of shops selling this cake that is round.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, so this is celebrated by the Chinese people.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: It's appreciation of the moon, I would say, this festival.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, there are of course legends associated with this Mooncake Festival.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Okay, and %uh they also have this Lantern Festival?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes, it's actually %uh Mooncake and together it's the Lantern Festival.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So we will eat mooncake, the children will carry lanterns.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh and just walk around where they live.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: This happen for just a whole day or it happen for a week?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Do you have this celebration for a week?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, we do have like in our housing estate, the children can actually walk around with a lantern but otherwise it's only for a particular day.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: It should be somewhere in September.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, but- yah, but anyway throughout this whole month, you'll see a lot of shop selling this mooncake.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: A lot of shops will be selling the lanterns %uh as well.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you get this %uh mooncake %uh kind of festival mood throughout the whole month.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So they have this parade as well?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: You know %uh I saw on TV that they have this %um Parade of Buddha.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Is it the one celebrated in the Mooncake Festival too?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh no. Usually the mooncake %uh we just have mooncakes to eat and the children will carry or even the adults carry lanterns %uh that's about it for the Lantern Festival.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Okay %um could you also please %uh give me a bit description about this %uh festival about the Nine Emperor Gods.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay, this is %uh not like a nationwide festival.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: okay, you know, the Chinese have so many different gods.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So this is just a festival that is celebrated.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: We have a temple in- somewhere in the Eastern part of Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah %uh so basically it's one of these gods %uh %uh festival, that's about it.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So the Chinese will offer food and offering %uh to the Gods.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So usually people just offer %uh foods to the Gods.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah, that's right for the particular God's birthday.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Okay, that's the only activity for this %uh day?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh if you are going to the temples in the Eastern part of Singapore, then yes, they are- it's quite %uh festive.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You'll see a lot of people offering prayers.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh otherwise it is not like a nationwide kind of %uh festival.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: The major festival would be like Chinese New Year.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Deepavali, Hari Raya and Christmas eve.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Chinese New Year, if you are down in January Feb- %uh January period.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh again very festival-like because we have a lot more shop selling Chinese New Year cookies %uh decorations so it's a very kind of a festive mood.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Then Hari Raya would be again very festive but it will be either in Kampong Glam or another area called Geylang.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Again, people are selling food associated with the celebration of Hari Raya.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh for the whole family to wear when they visit one another.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh Deepavali, quite similar to the other two festivals.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And of course Christmas time in December, we decorate all the buildings along Orchard Road right up to the Marina Square.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: So the major %um- one of the major %uh festival that you have is %uh the Chinese New Year, right?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: I think %uh- %Uh Chinese New Year, Hari Raya, Deepavali and Christmas, that's where everybody celebrate.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: The- this is where- oh okay.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %um September, we don't really have a ma- %uh sorry, April, we don't really have a major festival but %uh Good Friday, it's %uh our pub- one of our public holidays here.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: But %uh do you have any %um activities and any other activities %um within the month of April like a summer day, you know wherein I can enjoy anything under the sun.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh we don't have a summer day but because %uh well, we are in the equator so it's summer throughout the whole year.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh no major festival like I said in %uh April.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So %uh but otherwise it's still busy.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Alright, we are still busy and we still have a lot of tourist coming in throughout the whole year.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you still get this very festival %uh mood in Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Okay, have a great day, bye.
